Package org.apache.logging.log4j.core.config

Interface Configuration

All Superinterfaces:
Filterable, LifeCycle
All Known Implementing Classes:
AbstractConfiguration, BuiltConfiguration, CompositeConfiguration, DefaultConfiguration, JsonConfiguration, NullConfiguration, XmlConfiguration
public interface Configuration extends Filterable
Interface that must be implemented to create a configuration.

Custom implementations are recommended to extend AbstractConfiguration.

See Also:
  • AbstractConfiguration

  • Nested Class Summary

    Nested classes/interfaces inherited from interface org.apache.logging.log4j.core.LifeCycle

      LoggerConfig getLoggerConfig(String name)
      Locates the appropriate LoggerConfig for a Logger name. This will remove tokens from the package name as necessary or return the root LoggerConfig if no other matches were found.
      Parameters:
      name - The Logger name.
      Returns:
      The located LoggerConfig.

    • getProperties

      Map<String,String> getProperties()
      Returns the configuration properties. These will initially include entries for contextName with the context name and hostName with the local host name. Additional properties may be defined by plugins.

    • getCustomLevels

      List<CustomLevelConfig> getCustomLevels()

      Returns a list of descriptors of the custom levels defined in the current configuration. The returned list does not include custom levels that are defined in code with direct calls to Level.forName(String, int).

      Note that the list does not include levels of previous configurations. For example, suppose a configuration contains custom levels A, B and C. The configuration is then modified to contain custom levels B, C and D. For the new configuration, this method will return only {B, C, D}, that is, only the custom levels defined in this configuration. The previously defined level A still exists (and can be obtained with Level.getLevel(String)), it is just not in the current configuration. Level.values() will return {A, B, C, D and the built-in levels}.

      Returns:
      the custom levels defined in the current configuration

    • addExtensionIfAbsent

      <T extends ConfigurationExtension> T addExtensionIfAbsent(Class<T> extensionType, Supplier<? extends T> supplier)
      Registers a new configuration extension, if it doesn't exist.

      To preventing polluting the main configuration element, each JAR that wishes to extend the Configuration should use a single child element.

      Parameters:
      extensionType - the concrete type of the extension,
      supplier - a factory to create a new extension element,
      Returns:
      the current extension if present or a newly generated one.
      Since:
      3.0
      See Also:
      • getExtension(Class)

    • getExtension

      <T extends ConfigurationExtension> T getExtension(Class<T> extensionType)
      Returns an extension of the given type.

      Only the first extension of the given type is returned.

      Parameters:
      extensionType - a concrete type of the extension,
      Returns:
      an extension the matches the given type.
      Since:
      3.0
